REPORT. Eo the Honorable John H Micke. rnor, ami the Board f Public Lands and Buildin. utlemen : — I have the honor to submit the following report be biennium ending Novemlx I am glad to be ai i»>rt that there will be but few de - 1 the funds in which there are deficiencies are I • minended larger appropriations for. The improve - r which appropriations were made consist of an addi - to the brick hospital, fire proof coal house, iron roof to boil - ei house, and a rn. The folio* rovements were made from the cash fund: uhouse : brick root house in which we store 1,500 addition of f> stalls to horse barn; frame store ft. : also a i with the others mill iine. The cost of this cottage did not come li fund proper, but was built by money bequeathed for that pi: ud donations by two (2) of the In the all buildings, (excepting the main build ;nted. pi >r ealcimined. The main building painted with mineral paint over the soft brick on out- B calcimined and er- ings on part kWith this you will find estimate for coming biennium. I have refull ,f the home, and ask for no more an the iiureasc. and ] warrant me in doing. On . e had a membership of 464 ; on Xovem - '•. 1906 we had 507 making a net gain of 43 members. We have on file the applications of 20 women whom we can - account of no room, and 5 men whose applications n approved, but not yet reported. In addition to this have had a great many letters from old comrades making in - quiries as to admission of th > and wives, but. when they learn that women cannot be admitted for want of room, say that thev will starve it out together.

I do think that additional room should be provided or that law of admission be changed. I call attention to the re- port of the surgeon as to need of additional room in hospital. Two years ago I urged that an appropriation of twenty-five thou- sand ($25,000) dollars be made for a new building here to re- the present crowded condition and to provide for the fu- ture. I shall again urge this appropriation. Thanking the governor and the board for courtesies shown, and the officers and members of the home for efficient help and cheerful compliance of the rules, I am Respectfully W. S. ASKWITH. Askwith, Commandant: Dear Sir : — Herewith I submit my report for the biennium end- ing November 30, 1 There has been since the report of November 30, 1904 deaths — 65 men and 17 women — 63 died at the home and 19 away on furlough; but 2 more deaths at the home this biennium than during the prior one, yet the total membership is 43 more now than two years ago. With each passing year all are be< fijnjg more and more enfeebled. The addition to the west hospital was not completed until the 2nth of March, the present year. At that date we commenced tising it, although before its acceptance from the contractor by the Board of Public Lands and Buildings, because of the extreme '-*

370 of the b I will say that the work - -hiji in that part of tin- building is the beat in the brick >ital. Tl help, relieving the _■ that tl us room f" 1 b. Twen - ihiin are n< During tl. n there have >-k ;iiul invalid members admitted, who had to Jl the available :s taken, ;ll sicken from among the more healthy meml I Another add liould be immediately built to m <>rdf i the ameagem the veterans and their wives. IB for 1 -adly needed and a larger dining MB also. With the other addition this must come, for with greater number of patiei required, and oni for their accommodation. The roof over the dining d kit' raised I :ories and the room acquired t up int" lor help, then the rooms now occupied then i and family as formerly plan - d. but long si n up to old ladies and the help. An appropriation should be made for building porches the whole length of the south front of the ■ ;>ital. It would shade from the heat of the summer sun the south rooms, making rhem much more comfortable for the sick. The convalescents and feeble could gather on them and take out door air and ex - ercise a great portion of the time in pleasant weather. The present small porch in hot and pleasant weather is nearly al - ways crowded. In the autumn of 1903. by order of the state architect all the toilets were changed to automatic flushing bowls. They have all proven very unsatisfactory, failing to work, keeping the hos - pital in an unsanitary condition — the absent minded and feeble unable or Hush each time with a bucket water. I recommend their removal, to be replaced with "full" flushing toilets and porcelain lined iron tanks. There will be needed for drugs and instruments for the next Hennium a $3,000 appropriation.
